case_name: Shri Ananta Mukhi Ananta Hari v. District Magistrate Midnapore

facts.text: District Magistrate Midnapore issued detention order No. 97/C dated 24-4-71 against Shri Ananta Mukhi Ananta Hari son of Gobardhan Gurai of Antpara Chakbazir PS Debra Dt Midnapore to prevent him from acting prejudicial to security of State or maintenance of public order under section 3(1) read with 3(3) of West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act 1970

anchor.surface_text: ORDER No. 97/C Dated 24-4-71 Whereas I am satisfied with respect to the person known as Shri Ananta Mukhi, Ananta Hari, son of Gobardhan, Gurai of Antpara, Chakbazir, P. S. Debra, Dt. Midnapore that with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order, it is necessary so to do, I therefore in exercise of the powers companyferred by sub-section  1  read with sub-section  3  of section 3 of the West Bengal  Prevention of Violent Activities  Act, 1970  Presidents Act No. 19 of 1970  make this order directing that the said Shri Ananta Mukhi Ananta Hari be detained.

facts.text: Petitioner Ananta Mukhi was arrested on May 5 1971 and served with detention order grounds and vernacular translation on the same day

anchor.surface_text: He was arrested on May 5, 1971 and was served with the order of detention along with the ground of detention and the vernacular translation thereof on the same day.

facts.text: On 4-10-69 at about 21-30 hrs petitioner along with 50/60 Naxalite supporters armed with lethal weapons raided house of Shri Pulin Bihari Mandal of Bhuiyabasan P Debra looted cash ornaments utensils worth Rs 10000

anchor.surface_text: That on 4-10-69, at about 21-30 hrs., you along with 50/60 Naxalite supporters being am- led with lethal weapons raided the house of Shri Pulin Bihari Maiidal of Bhuiyabasan, P. Debra in order to kill him. The house owner somehow managed to save his life. You and your associates then looted cash, orna- ments, utensils and other properties worth about Rs. 10,000 from the house.

facts.text: On 8-11-69 at about 20.00 hrs petitioner along with 20/22 Naxalite workers armed with lethal weapons raided house of Shri Bistu Pada Bhuiya of Radhakantapur PS Debra killed his brothers Madan Bhuiya and Kshudiram Bhuiya looted ornaments articles

anchor.surface_text: That on 8-11-69, at about 20.00 hrs., you along with 20/22 Naxalite workers armed with lethal weapons raided the house of Shri Bistu Pada Bhuiya of Radhakantapur, P. S. Debra and killed his two brothers named Madan Bhuiya and Kshudiram Bhuiya by sharp cutting weapons. You and your associates also looted ornaments and other articles from the house.

facts.text: District Magistrate reported detention order to State Government on April 26 1971

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1971 the District Magistrate of Midnapore reported to the State Government about the making of the detention order against the petitioner together with the grounds of detention and other necessary particulars.

facts.text: State Government approved detention order on May 4 1971 and submitted report to Central Government same day

anchor.surface_text: The said report and particulars were companysidered by the State Government and on May 4, 1971 the detention order was approved by the State Government. On the same day the State Government submitted a report to the Central Government together with the grounds of detention and other necessary particulars.

facts.text: Petitioner submitted representation dated May 13 1971 received by State Government on May 20 1971 rejected on June 2 1971

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, on May 20, 1971 the State Government received a representation of the petitioner dated May 13, 1971. The said representation was companysidered by the State Government and was rejected as per order dated June 2, 1971.

facts.text: State Government placed case before Advisory Board on June 3 1971 Advisory Board report dated July 8 1971 opining sufficient cause for detention

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioner was placed by the State Government before the Advisory Board on June 3, 1971. ... The Advisory Board after companysidering the material before it, including the representation of the petitioner, and after hearing him in person, sent its report to the State Government on July 8, 1971. Opinion was expressed by the Advisory Board that there. was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on July 16 1971

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated July 16, 1971 the State Government companyfirmed the order of detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: Petition is Writ Petition No 322 of 1971 under Article 32 in original jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 322 of 1971. K. Jain, for the petitioner. L. Mukhoty and G. S. Chatterjee, for the respondent. M. SHELAT, J. gave a dissenting opinion. The Judgment of R. KHANNA and K. K. MATHEW, JJ. was delivered by KHANNA, J.

facts.text: President issued Proclamation dated March 19 1970 under Article 356 assuming functions of West Bengal government

anchor.surface_text: By a Proclamation, dated March 19, 1970, made under Art. 356 of the Constitution, the President of India, being satisfied that a situation had arisen in which government in West Bengal companyld number be carried on in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution, assumed to himself the functions of government of that State

facts.text: Parliament enacted West Bengal State Legislature Delegation of Powers Act XVII of 1970 on April 29 1970

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the said Proclamation, Parliament enacted, on April 29, 1970, the West Bengal State Legislature  Delegation of Powers  Act, XVII of 1970, under sec. 3 of which the State Legislatures power to make laws was companyferred on the President

facts.text: President enacted West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act 1970 President's Act No 19 of 1970

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companytained in Act XVII of 1970, the President enacted the President Act XIX of 1970. Since that Act was enacted in exercise of and in accordance with the powers of the State Legislature, the Act providing for preventive detention companyld be passed in terms and within the scope of entry 3 of the Concurrent List

facts.text: Petitioner was absconding soon after detention order and arrested on May 5 1971

anchor.surface_text: Soon after the detention order, the petitioner was found to be absconding. He was arrested on May 5, 1971

facts.text: Activities in grounds of detention fall under clause d of section 3(2) as offences punishable with death or life imprisonment or 7 years and disturb public order

anchor.surface_text: The above facts would show that the case against the petitioner was companyered by clause  d  of subsection  2  of section 3 of the Act. ... The first allegation discloses that the petitioner and his associates were guilty of dacoity, while the second allegation shows that at the time of the companymission of the offence of dacoity, the petitioner and his associates also murdered two persons.

facts.text: Shelat J gave dissenting opinion holding detention invalid due to use of disjunctive or in order

anchor.surface_text: M. SHELAT, J. gave a dissenting opinion. The Judgment of R. KHANNA and K. K. MATHEW, JJ. was delivered by KHANNA, J. Shelat J., The order of detention impugned in this petition is as follows

facts.text: Majority by Khanna J dismissed the petition upholding validity of detention order

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the petition fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Advisory Board heard petitioner in person

anchor.surface_text: The Advisory Board after companysidering the material before it, including the representation of the petitioner, and after hearing him in person, sent its report

facts.text: Affidavit filed by Shri Manoranjan Dey Assistant Secretary Home Special Department Government of West Bengal in opposition

anchor.surface_text: The petition has been resisted by the respondents and the affidavit of Shri Manoranjan Dey, Assistant Secretary, Home  Special  Department, Government of West Bengal has been filed in opposition to the petition.

facts.text: Acts disturbed public order and petitioner became terror to residents of locality

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid activities of the petitioner, according to the affidavit of Shri Manoranjan Dey, disturbed public order and the petitioner became a terror to the residents of the locality.

arguments.claim: s.3(2) provides comprehensive definition of 'acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order'; acts in clauses a-e fall within the compendious expression

holdings.text: The case against the petitioner was covered by clause (d) of sub-section (2) of section 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The above facts would show that the case against the petitioner was covered by clause d of subsection 2 of section 3 of the Act. Sub-sections 1 and 2 of section 3 of the Act read as under The State Government may, if satisfied with respect to any person that with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order, it is necessary so to do, make an order directing that such person be detained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First allegation discloses dacoity, second dacoity with murder; offences punishable with death, life imprisonment or 7+ years.

holdings.text: The aforesaid activities of the petitioner disturbed public order and the petitioner became a terror to the residents of the locality.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid activities of the petitioner, according to the affidavit of Shri Manoranjan Dey, disturbed public order and the petitioner became a terror to the residents of the locality. We see no cogent ground to take a different view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts affidavit evidence; large groups of armed Naxalites committing dacoity and murder disturb public order.

holdings.text: When such a large number of persons, who were stated to be Naxalite workers, armed with lethal weapons commit the offence of dacoity and dacoity with murder, such offences disturb or are likely to disturb public order.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that when such a large number of persons, who were stated to be Naxalite workers, armed with lethal weapons commit the offence of dacoity and dacoity with murder, such offences disturb or are likely to disturb public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Degree and extent of acts (armed raids by groups) reach public order per three concentric circles test.

holdings.text: The activities of the petitioner as mentioned in the grounds of detention show that they were not of an extraneous character but fell within the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of State or the maintenance of public order as defined in sub-section 2 of section 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The activities of the petitioner as mentioned in the grounds of detention, in our opinion, show that they were not of an extraneous character but fell within the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of State or the maintenance of public order as defined in sub-section 2 of section 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds supplied under s.8(1); facts fit s.3(2)(d).

holdings.text: A comprehensive definition has been given of the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order; the various acts specified fall within the compendious expression.

anchor.surface_text: We have reproduced subsection 2 of section 3 of the Act earlier and it would appear therefrom that a comprehensive definition has been given of the expression acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(2) clubs security and public order with 'or'; no separate definitions.

holdings.text: The use of the word 'or' in the detention order does not introduce infirmity; mirrors the disjunctive 'or' in s.3(2) definition; no casualness or absence of application of mind.

anchor.surface_text: The presence of the word or in the definition itself tends to show that the use of that word in the order is not impermissible and there was no element of casualness or absence of due application of the mind in the making of the impugned order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition treats activities as prejudicial to either/both; distinguishes statutes with separate grounds.

holdings.text: The above conclusion fortified by Shyamal Mondal v. State of West Bengal; grounds not vague; order valid.

anchor.surface_text: We are fortified in the above conclusion by a recent decision of this Court in the case of Shyamal Mondal v. State of West Bengal. In that case too the impugned order of detention stated that the District Magistrate was satisfied...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows recent precedent on identical language and definition.

holdings.text: Disturbance of public order may prejudicially affect security of State; close nexus allows overlap.

anchor.surface_text: That, disturbance of public order in a State may in turn prejudicially affect its security, is also undeniable. Fairly close and rational nexus between these clauses and the maintenance of public order and security of the State of West Bengal is writ large on the face of these clauses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Ashok Dey; concentric circles allow overlap.

holdings.text: The detention order is lawfully made despite reciting satisfaction re prejudicial to security of State or maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls for determination in this petition is whether detention directed by an order which recites that it was made upon satisfaction of the District Magistrate that the person concerned was acting in a manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the

holdings.text: The impugned order of detention rendered vague and indefinite due to disjunctive 'or'; mechanical reproduction; detention bad.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the construction urged by counsel for the petitioner has to be accepted and it must be held that the use of the disjunctive or in the impugned order rendered the order of detention vague and indefinite, indicative of the detaining authority having merely reproduced mechanically the language of sec. 3 (1) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(2) requires authority to specify ground (security or public order) based on extent; distinguishes Shyamal Mondal.

precedents.citation: Dr. R. M. Lohia v. Bihar 1

anchor.surface_text: Dr. R. M. Lohia v. Bihar 1 , the impugned detention order was passed under r. 30 1  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962 which required satisfaction of the detaining authority that the person concerned should be prevented from acting in a manner prejudicial inter alia, to the public safety and the maintenance of public order. The order impugned there stated that the authority was satisfied that it was necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to prevent him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the public safety and maintenance of law and order.

precedents.case_name: Dr R M Lohia v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between law and order, public order and security of the State visualized as three concentric circles
precedents.cited_holding: One has to imagine three concentric circles, the largest representing law and order, the next representing public order and the smallest representing security of State.

anchor.surface_text: Pushkar Mukherjee v. West Bengal 1  by a caution therein that the expression public order in sec. 3 1  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950 did not take in every infraction of law. It was observed that the contravention of any law always affects order, but before it-can be said to affect public order, it must affect the community or the public at large.

precedents.case_name: Pushkar Mukherjee v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between law and order and public order; contravention of law affects order but not necessarily public order unless it affects community at large

anchor.surface_text: Arun Ghosh v. West Bengal 2 , in the degree and extent of the reach of the act in question upon society. Acts similar in nature, but committed in different contexts and circumstances might cause different reactions. In one case, it might affect the problem of law and order, and in another, though similar in quality, of public order.

precedents.case_name: Arun Ghosh v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between law and order, public order lies in degree and extent of reach of the act upon society

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath Mondal v. West Bengal 3

anchor.surface_text: see also Nagendra Nath Mondal v. West Bengal 3 . An act, such as committing the defence secrets of a country to an enemy country, while not affecting the maintenance of law and order or public order, would affect adversely the security of the State.

precedents.case_name: Nagendra Nath Mondal v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between concepts of law and order, public order, security of State

anchor.surface_text: Shyamal Mondal v. West Bengal 1 The impugned order there stated that the District Magistrate was satisfied that it was necessary that the petitioner should be detained with a view to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order.

precedents.case_name: Shyamal Mondal v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: acts falling under clauses (a) to (e) of section 3(2) are prejudicial to both security of State and public order

anchor.surface_text: as held by this Court in the case of Jagannath Misra State of Orissa. 1 The detenu in that case had been ordered to be detained under rule 30 1  b  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962 and according to the order of detention, the order had been made with a view to preventing the detenu from acting in any manner prejudicial to the defence of India and civil defence,

precedents.case_name: Jagannath Misra v State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: use of disjunctive 'or' between multiple grounds in detention order indicates casualness and non-application of mind
precedents.cited_holding: Where a number of grounds are the basis of a detention order, we would expect the various grounds to be joined by the conjunctive and the use of the disjunctive or in such a case makes no sense.

precedents.citation: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar and Ors. 1

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar and Ors. 1 , this Court while expounding the words maintenance of public order observed one has to imagine three concentric circles Law and order represents the largest circle within which is the next circle representing public order and the smallest circle represents the security of the State.

precedents.case_name: Dr Ram Manohar Lohia v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: three concentric circles: law and order (largest), public order (next), security of State (smallest)

precedents.citation: Madhu Limaye v. Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Monghyr and Ors. 2

anchor.surface_text: Madhu Limaye v. Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Monghyr and Ors. 2  and it was observed The expression public order includes absence of all acts which are a danger to the security of the State and also acts which are comprehended by the expression order public explained above but not acts which disturb only the serenity of others.

precedents.case_name: Madhu Limaye v Sub-Divisional Magistrate Monghyr
precedents.cited_proposition: public order includes acts dangerous to security of State but not mere disturbances of serenity

precedents.citation: State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey Ors. etc. etc. Cr. Apptal No. 217 to 223 of 1971 decided on November 19, 1971

anchor.surface_text: State of West Bengal v. Ashok Dey Ors. etc. etc. Cr. Apptal No. 217 to 223 of 1971 decided on November 19, 1971 while dealing with different clauses of section 3, this Court observed That, disturbance of public order in a State may in turn prejudicially affect its security, is also undeniable.

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v Ashok Dey
precedents.cited_proposition: disturbance of public order may prejudicially affect security of State; close nexus between clauses and public order/security

precedents.citation: Shyamal Mondal v. State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Shyamal Mondal v. State of West Bengal 1 . In that case too the impugned order of detention stated that the District Magistrate was satisfied that it was necessary that, the petitioner should be detained with a view to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order as provided by section 3 1 ,of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Shyamal Mondal v State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: acts under section 3(2) clauses (a)-(e) prejudicial to security of State or public order; use of 'or' valid due to definition
precedents.cited_holding: a perusal of clauses a to e clearly shows that any of the matters referred to therein will be both prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The above facts would show that the case against the petitioner was covered by clause d of subsection 2 of section 3 of the Act. Sub-sections 1 and 2 of section 3 of the Act read as under The State Government may, if satisfied with respect to any person that with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order, it is necessary so to do, make an order directing that such person be detained.
The result is that the petition fails and is dismissed.
